Hi, @nixonrodrigues. Thanks for your comments. This patch is very minor, so I didnâ€™t create a JIRA for it.
+1 for the PR, thanks @asdf2014
@nixonrodrigues You are very welcome

- adding a field for 'key' in HookNotification and EntityNotification might be a simpler/smaller change. I suggest to consider this  approach.
- how are the keys generated, and where are they assigned to each notification being sent? I could see this in unit tests. Can you please point to appropriate code lines?

>     * adding a field for 'key' in HookNotification and EntityNotification might be a simpler/smaller change. I suggest to consider this  approach.

I'm trying this now, but it doesn't seem like it works conceptually.

For instance, it seems that `HookNotification` is extended by `EntityCreateRequestV2`. This extension, however, seems to pack in multiple entities via `AtlasEntitiesWithExtInfo`, meaning that there is no single key that `HookNotification` can use.

I think I need some help conceptually here: Is `HookNotification` and `EntityNotification` supposed to be a bundle of an arbitrary number of entities? I was originally under the impression that there were meant to be 1:1 (eg: one EntityNotification per entity).
Thanks  @zyyBjtu for PR, It looked good. I have merged it.

> Can you please provide more context about the usecase and how this patch helps?

When user rename hive table with other db name by executing:
`ALTER TABLE db1.table RENAME TO db2.table`

HMS hook will send `ALTERTABLE_PROPERTIES` event msg instead of `ALTERTABLE_RENAME` (HiveMetastoreHookImpl#onAlterTable), causing old table still cant be found.
Issue link - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ATLAS-4358

I've fixed a merge resolution error that actually downgraded Elasticsearch.
Also reverted some changes for test dependencies which are not really needed by this PR.
Could someone please schedule one more PreCommit for this PR? Thank you!

> Could someone please schedule one more PreCommit for this PR? Thank you!

https://ci-builds.apache.org/job/Atlas/job/PreCommit-ATLAS-Build-Test/835/console

OK! 
I was able to reproduce the issue on a fresh setup/checkout of Atlas. It was that Solr 8.6.3 depended on ZooKeeper 3.5.7 and there is an API break in 3.6.2. Upgrading to Solr 3.7.0 fixes the issue.
cc : @ashutoshm , can you review this ?
@mehtaanshul Thanks for the PR. I am in the process of verifying this change.
@mehtaanshul , can you add an explanation on why we need to move the java patch registration from init() to applyAll() method?
missed the details from JIRA, ignore my prev comment.

Thanks for the details Anshul Mehta. I have a question:

Internal patch attributes like "**__createdBy, __modifiedBy, __timestamp, __modificationTimestamp, __patch.id, __patch.description, __patch.type, __patch.action, __patch.state**" are created in GraphBackedSearchIndexer which is Spring annotated component with Order(1)

The AtlasPatchService has an Order(3), so the internal indexes should be created before Patch Manager is initialized right? Do you see a race scenario where the init() happens during dependency injection of AtlasPatchManager in AtlasPatchService?
Could someone run a PreCommit job please? Thank you!
Ping!

Apache Storm 2.3.0 has been released recently - http://storm.apache.org/2021/09/27/storm230-released.html.
Please let me know if you prefer this PR to upgrade to 2.3.0 instead of 2.2.0!
Please open a PR.

> Please open a PR.

What do you mean, @ashutoshm  ?
This is a PR.
You are right. I was thinking that you would raise a separate PR for upgrading to 2.3.0. You can instead modify this one. That will work as well.
OK! I will test it first on Linux ARM64 tomorrow and if everything works I will update this PR!
@ashutoshm The build passed here with Storm 2.3.0. I've updated this PR!
Ping!
Ping!

We were updating our CI build for the past week.

I have started CI with this change. I will commit the change once CI passes.

Here is the brief report that illustrates the problem:

`<<< FAILURE! - in org.apache.atlas.repository.graphdb.janus.AtlasJanusGraphIndexClientTest
[ERROR] org.apache.atlas.repository.graphdb.janus.AtlasJanusGraphIndexClientTest.testGenerateSearchWeightString  Time elapsed: 0.182 s  <<< FAILURE!
java.lang.AssertionError: expected [ one^10 two^1 three^15] but found [ three^15 two^1 one^10]
	at org.apache.atlas.repository.graphdb.janus.AtlasJanusGraphIndexClientTest.testGenerateSearchWeightString(AtlasJanusGraphIndexClientTest.java:120)
`

Python 3.6 already reached end of life (23.12.2021), 2.7 is not supported since 01.01.2020. A lot of packages already dropped support of such old Python versions, why bother keeping it?
@kevalbhatt  @pinal-shah @mandarambawane @mneethiraj Any activity on the *Python Client*?
@bdsoha  - thank you for the fix. Changes look good. I created [ATLAS-4704](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ATLAS-4704) to track this fix. The fix will be merged shortly.
@yanxu3ms  - thank you for the fix. Changes look good. I created [ATLAS-4705](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ATLAS-4705) to track this fix. The fix will be merged shortly.

@Anandkarthick - thank you for the patch. APIs to retrieve typeDefs and typeDefHeaders do support search parameters, like: type, name, supertype, servicetype, notsupertype, notservicetype, notname. Hence searchFilter parameter in Python method is useful to send necessary filters.
